metadata.title: Microsoft employee protests lead to 18 arrests as company reviews its work with Israel’s military

left: Dozens of Microsoft employees protested against the Israeli military's use of Microsoft's software to surveil Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank at the company's Washington campus on August 20, 2025.
Microsoft launched an urgent external investigation following claims that the Israeli Defense Forces used its Azure platform for mass surveillance of Palestinians.
Protesters demanded that Microsoft cut business ties with Israel, leading to several arrests as they continued to occupy the campus and display signs against the military contracts.
A Microsoft spokesperson confirmed that protesters complied with police orders during the two-hour protest at the company’s campus.
center: Worker-Led protests erupted at Microsoft headquarters this week as the tech company promises an urgent review of the Israeli military's use of its technology during the ongoing war in Gaza.

Microsoft said it was tapping a law firm to investigate allegations reported by The Guardian that the Israeli Defense Forces used Microsoft's Azure cloud computing platform to store phone call data obtained through the mass surveillance of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank.
The Redmond Police Department confirmed that several protesters have been arrested after Microsoft said the protesters were trespassing.
right: Dozens of Microsoft employees protested, urging the company to end its ties with Israel over allegations its software is being used in Gaza, as reported by the Guardian.
Members of the group No Azure for Genocide organized the protest, claiming that Microsoft is complicit in Israeli military actions.
Microsoft stated it would review claims that its Azure cloud platform was used to store recordings of Palestinian conversations, according to +972 Magazine.
Protesters intensified their actions after the killing of journalist Anas al-Sharif, with former employee Hossam Nasr stating that al-Sharif's death compelled him to act.
